TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {98=The division insignia consists of a white trident on a blue shield within a white border. Neptune's trident was originally adopted to represent the coastal states of Maine, Vermont and New Hampshire, from which personnel for the division was draw in 1918. The three prongs of the trident represent the three states; the blue symbolizes the states numerous fresh water lakes; and, the white of the border and trident represents the snow that covers these states' picturesque mountains.}
textBeforeTable: Commanding General   COMMAND AND STAFF   [page 358]   The division insignia consists of a white trident on a blue shield within a white border. Neptune's trident was originally adopted to represent the coastal states of Maine, Vermont and New Hampshire, from which personnel for the division was draw in 1918. The three prongs of the trident represent the three states; the blue symbolizes the states numerous fresh water lakes; and, the white of the border and trident represents the snow that covers these states' picturesque mountains.   97th INFANTRY DIVISION
textAfterTable: 1 Mar 45 Lt. Col. Julian R. Alford Commanding Officer, 303d Infantry 1 Mar 45 Col. William B. Forse Commanding Officer, 386th Infantry 1 Mar 45 Col. Samuel M. Lansing Commanding Officer, 387th Infantry 1 Mar 45 Col. William D. Long   [page 359]   STATISTICS   Chronology Activated 25 February 1943 Arrived ETO 3 March 1945 Arrived Continent (D+272) 5 March 1945 Entered Combat--First Elements 31 March 1945 Entered Combat--Entire Division 1 April 1945 Days in Combat 31   Casualties (Tentative) Killed 178 Wounded 669 Missing 87 Captured   Battle Casualties 934 Non-Battle Casualties 384 Total Casualties 1,318 Percent of T/O Strength 9.4
